awd_titl_txt: Effect of Visualization on Undergraduate Students' Understanding of Fundamental Probability Concepts, Including Bayesian Inference
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR) Program, this project aims to serve the national interest in high-quality undergraduate STEM education.  It will do so by developing and researching visualization resources that may promote learning in undergraduate statistics.  Helping students understand basic probability concepts is critical to promote science literacy, as well as to equip STEM majors with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed in graduate school, the workplace, and beyond. This project will develop and test a learning module on the probability concepts involved in Bayesian inference, a procedure for updating probability in response to new data. The project will also explore the role of visualization in learning probability concepts by comparing visual and non-visual versions of the learning module. The instructional materials created for the project may help educators include Bayesian inference in their courses.  This inclusion is important because Bayesian inference is an increasingly important concept across many  STEM fields, and the instructional modules may promote STEM success for a wide range of students. More broadly, the findings may reveal principles that can guide future efforts to create instructional methods that make difficult mathematical concepts more accessible to students, especially those who struggle with math.

Both versions of the Bayesian inference learning module will incorporate innovations from basic research.  The visual version will also use a display that links mathematical concepts to simple spatial relationships. Students in discussion sections of an introductory statistics class will complete either the visual or non-visual versions of the module, and their understanding will be assessed by the accuracy of their responses on assignments and qualitative responses in one-on-one interviews. The primary research questions are: (1) Does the visual representation facilitate active learning and intuitive understanding by increasing performance on problems that challenge students to apply statistical reasoning before getting direct instruction? (2) Does the visual representation produce more durable learning as evidenced by performance on computational problems completed one month after initial instruction? (3) Does the visual representation help students convey a deep conceptual understanding of probability concepts in interviews? and (4) Does the visual representation reduce the performance gap for students who either struggle with mathematical concepts or who have negative attitudes towards math? Both qualitative and quantitative methods will be used to seek the answers to these research questions. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the teaching of Bayesian inference and related probability concepts using a novel visualization technique, called the bar display, and the results have clear implications for the continued use of spatial representations of probability in the classroom setting and beyond. The bar display improved student performance and understanding in several ways, such as improving success on active learning exercises and providing the opportunity to catch and correct errors in calculation or problem interpretation. The bar display was particularly helpful for students who reported high math anxiety and/or low numerical skills. Guided interviews revealed that students with learning differences were able to use the bar display effectively, demonstrating that the technique is helpful for a wide range of students with diverse learning needs. A primary objective of the project was to cultivate instructional methods that increase student accessibility to STEM fields, and the results represent a step forward in achieving that goal. The results also provided useful guidance on the limits of the bar display, revealing that a visually-guided active learning approach was not effective for learning how to calculate joint probabilities, whereas this approach was highly effective for determining the posterior odds for Bayesian inference problems. Thus, the current project will help educators optimize education on probability concepts in an updated curriculum that includes Bayesian statistics.

Project activities involved creating an extensive set of coordinated educational materials, such as presentation slides, practice problems for classroom and homework assignments, and computer code to implement interactive spatial displays in a web browser. These materials are freely available to other researchers and educators on the Open Science Framework, a popular public repository. To further support instructors and students, the investigators also designed a workshop on Bayesian statistics for college faculty and graduate students. The workshop uses spatial representations to explain key concepts such as basic Bayesian inference, parameter estimation, and hierarchical modeling. Participants were encouraged to adopt the methods and materials in their own educational practices. The workshop was well-attended by a range of professionals from different domains, such as agriculture and economics, which speaks to the broad applicability of the spatial representations of probability investigated in this project. Educational practices relying on the bar display method were also disseminated to other researchers and educators in journal articles and conference presentations.

              The project activities inspired many ideas that can be investigated in future research, such as giving students access to interactive, as opposed to static, visual displays and exploring how spatial representations help students link related concepts, such as Bayesian hypothesis testing and parameter estimation. Thus, the project will continue to support the education and professional development of students at both the graduate and undergraduate levels. Research activities aided multiple students in completing Master’s thesis and undergraduate honor’s thesis projects, and students at both levels had authorship opportunities on journal articles and conference presentations.

              To summarize, project activities investigated a novel visualization technique for learning foundational probability concepts in a modernized statistics curriculum, and results have important implications for educational practices and future research endeavors. By creating and distributing instructional materials, the project supports curriculum development and student success across a wide range of student backgrounds and learning styles. Workshops and presentations will continue to provide educators with the opportunity to learn about statistical and probability concepts using spatial representations, which can then be applied within their own classrooms in a number of STEM topic areas.
